channel.title: NYT > U.S. > Politics

item.title: Judge Halts Transfer of Former Death Row Inmates to Federal ‘Supermax’ Facility
item.description: A judge ruled that the Trump administration’s plan to send the men to the nation’s harshest prison rendered their attempts to challenge the transfer a “sham” process.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buildings and guard towers at the federal corrections center in Florence, Colo., also known as the “Alcatraz of the Rockies.”

item.title: Trump Says He Will Now Invite Democrats to Governors’ Meeting
item.description: Even as he reversed course on excluding Democrats, the president repeatedly attacked a Republican governor who had planned to oversee the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump denied that he had ever sought to exclude Democrats from the meeting.

item.title: Eyeing the Midterms, Kennedy Pivots Toward Food and Away From Vaccines
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who focused heavily on vaccine policy in 2025, will spend this year talking up healthy eating.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the boxer Mike Tyson and Brooke Rollins, the agriculture secretary, at an event on Wednesday promoting Mr. Kennedy’s healthy eating agenda.

item.title: House Passes Strict Voter ID Bill, Amplifying Trump’s Claims of Fraud
item.description: The measure had no path forward in the Senate, where Democrats are all but certain to block it and Republicans have said they will not try to skirt filibuster rules to ram it through.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
item.media:description: The strict voter identification measure would require proof of American citizenship to vote and allow the Department of Homeland Security to seize voter rolls in any state.

item.title: Democratic Hopefuls in Michigan’s Senate Race Jostle for Union Support
item.description: Can Democrats win back working-class voters? These candidates are trying.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, the top Democratic Senate candidates in Michigan: Representative Haley Stevens, Dr. Abdul El-Sayed and State Senator Mallory McMorrow.

item.title: Democrats Denounce Attempt to Indict Lawmakers for Illegal Orders Video
item.description: Members in both chambers warned the failed attempt to prosecute the six lawmakers amounted to an existential threat to the legislative branch.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If the executive branch can merely attempt to prosecute members of the legislative branch for simply exercising free speech, that is not a Democratic problem or a Republican problem, it is a constitutional crisis,” said Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the minority leader.

item.title: Gallup Will No Longer Track Presidential Approval Ratings
item.description: The monthly poll has been used to measure presidential performance for almost nine decades.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gallup’s decision comes as President Trump has escalated his threats against the press, and has sued several news media organizations, including at least one pollster, over the last several years.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, suggested that the agency might eventually approve Moderna’s mRNA flu vaccine.

item.title: In North Carolina, a Tight Primary Could Upend the Balance of Conservative Power
item.description: Phil Berger has led the State Senate for years with an iron grip. But in a March election, he faces a popular, horse-riding sheriff who could topple his reign.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Cornell Watson for The New York Times

item.title: Ray Mouton Dies at 78; Lawyer Warned of Pedophilia in the Catholic Church
item.description: After defending one of the first priests charged with child sex abuse, he coauthored a 1985 report warning that the problem was endemic and ignoring it could be catastrophic.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: House Votes to Cancel Trump’s Canada Tariffs
item.description: Six Republicans joined nearly all Democrats to end the national emergency President Donald Trump had declared to impose tariffs on imports from Canada.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks crossing the Ambassador Bridge connecting Windsor, Canada, with Detroit.

item.title: Federal Debt to Hit Record Levels, Budget Office Warns
item.description: President Trump has reshaped the country’s economic policies, but the outlook for the budget remains dire.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The federal debt is expected to grow under President Trump, the Congressional Budget Office said in its latest forecast.

item.title: Trump Says ‘Nothing Definitive’ Came Out of Meeting With Netanyahu on Iran
item.description: Mr. Netanyahu moved up a visit to Washington to discuss Mr. Trump’s continuing negotiations over Iran’s nuclear and weapons program, which Israel considers an existential threat.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Florida last year.

item.title: Lawmakers Question Bondi Over Justice Dept. Under Her Watch
item.description: Her appearance came as the Justice Department was under scrutiny over the Epstein files, its approach toward the shootings in Minneapolis and its move to prosecute six lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Iran’s Missile Program Tops Israel’s Concerns as Netanyahu Meets Trump
item.description: President Trump is focused on Iran’s nuclear program, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sees a more immediate threat from Tehran’s rapid rebuilding of its ability to launch missiles at Israel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.media:credit: Menahem Kahana/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli air defenses intercepting Iranian missiles over Tel Aviv during the military conflict last June.

item.title: Fired Former Trump Prosecutor to Run for Congress in Virginia as a Democrat
item.description: J.P. Cooney, a former top deputy to the special counsel Jack Smith, who led two prosecutions of President Trump, plans to seek election to a newly drawn district in Northern and Central Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: J.P. Cooney said the “biggest catalyst” for his decision to run was the killing of Alex Pretti by federal agents in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: NATO Is Expected to Step Up Arctic Security. Here’s Why.
item.description: As Russia displays its military might in the Arctic region, the Western alliance is beginning a mission to increase its presence there.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Odd Andersen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Danish navy vessel patrolling the waters off Nuuk, Greenland, in March.

item.title: U.S. Brings Dozens of Foreign Military Chiefs to Washington
item.description: The rare gathering focused on the Western Hemisphere underscored potential implications of the Trump administration’s “Donroe Doctrine.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, convened the meeting in Washington.

item.title: Portland Lawsuit Alleges Tear Gas Use by ICE Is a Health Threat
item.description: A novel lawsuit in Portland argues the chemicals are a health threat that have soaked into apartment walls, furniture and even children’s toys.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: An October incident outside an ICE facility in Portland, Ore. Residents across the street have sued over the use of tear gas.

item.title: Homeland Security Hires Labor Dept. Aide Whose Posts Raised Alarms
item.description: A young aide behind social posts that echoed white supremacist messaging will help run social media for the much larger Homeland Security Department.
item.dc:creator: Evan Gorelick
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Peyton Rollins, a new social media director at the Department of Homeland Security, has claimed credit for a huge banner with President Trump’s visage that hung from the Labor Department’s headquarters.

item.title: After Trump’s Cuts, Some Former Federal Workers Are Now Seeking Office
item.description: A collection of former civil servants are waging first-time campaigns this year. Some said that President Trump’s attacks on the work force motivated them to run.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Laura Morton for The New York Times
